record.attribute:
EuPathDB (formerly ApiDB) is an integrated database covering the eukaryotic pathogens in the genera Cryptosporidium, Giardia, Leishmania, Neospora, Plasmodium, Toxoplasma, Trichomonas and Trypanosoma. While each of these groups is supported by a taxon-specific database built upon the same infrastructure, the EuPathDB portal offers an entry point to all of these resources, and the opportunity to leverage orthology for searches across genera.

The EuPathDB family of databases is expected to expanding further over the coming years, incorporate new species including the Amoebozoa (Entamoeba, Acanthamoebs), Microsporidia, and additional Apicomplexans, Kinetoplastida and Diplomonads.

Of course, we continue collecting data that are being deposited at an ever-increasing rate, including additional genome sequences, microarray data, probe-based hybridization and sequencing data (e.g. ChIP-chip and RNA-Seq), proteomics data, isolate data, phenotype information, metabolomic data, etc.

EST Assemblies

EST assemblies are transcript predictions based on genome alignments. ESTs are obtained from dbEST and from researchers who generously provide additional libraries. ESTs are cleaned prior to use; leading or trailing poly A or T sequences are trimmed and vector sequences are masked. ESTs greater than 50 bases long are used for BLAT alignment (Kent,W.J, 2002. Genome Research. 12:656-664) to same species genome sequences with a threshold of 90% minimum sequence identity, minimum score of 30, and the maximum intron length adjusted for the species. The ESTs are then clustered into disjoint sets based on the proximity and quality of their alignments, only the best alignments with a 95% minimum percent identity are used for clustering. Clusters of ESTs are then assembled and consensus sequences produced using the CAP4 assembly program (X. Huang and Madan, A., 1999. Genome Res. 9:868-877). Finally, the predicted consensus transcripts are themselves aligned to the genome.

For more detail on Methods please access
CryptoDB.org: Data Sources,    Methods,    SOPs for annotation.
GiardiaDB.org: Data Sources,    Methods
PlasmoDB.org: Data Sources,    Methods
ToxoDB.org: Data Sources,    Methods
TrichDB.org: Data Sources,    Methods
TriTrypDB.org: Data Sources,    Methods

There are two main kinds of downloads available in a EuPathDB site:
  • Download Files that have been created at release time. The link to access these is under the menu item "Download", under "Data Files".
  • Download files that are generated by running queries. From a result page (after running a query) a user can access the "Download Resuts" link, to a new page where a few different options are offered to construct a file for download with the set of IDs in the result.

The Eukaryotic Pathogen Database (EuPathDB) has been developed as a Bioinformatics Resource Center (BRC), with support from the US National Institutes of Health (NIH). Additional funding for a kinetoplastid component (TriTrypDB) was recently provided by the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, in coordination with independent support for kinetoplastid annotation from the Wellcome Trust.

The data at this site is provided freely for public use, through the contributions of many researchers including those involved in generating the genome sequences. The data is not guaranteed to be accurate as it often reflects the results of ongoing research. When using data obtained from EuPathDB, it is important to cite the original publications and contributors of that data and EuPathDB. Please see Citing EuPathDB below.

When citing EuPathDB itself, please use:

ApiDB: integrated resources for the apicomplexan bioinformatics resource center. 2007 Jan;35(Database issue):D427-30. Aurrecoechea C, et al.

Much of the data in EuPathDB is provided by independent researchers. Please cite them if you use their data. For a list of the data integrated into EuPathDB and the related publications please see Data Sources.
